SingerÂ Joy Villa , who upstaged Sunday’s Grammy Awards by wearing a pro-President Donald Trump gown to the ceremony, is calling on her fans to keep up the momentum. 
Upon arriving at the show, Villa took off a white robe revealing a red, white and blue gown bearing Trump’s slogan âMake America Great Again.â In addition, âTrumpâ was sewn in glitter on the hem.

“Find the nearest person who does not believe with you in supporting Trump or believing in your political viewpoints. Maybe theyâre not conservative or theyâre too far conservative,” she said. Advertisement - story continues below

In addition to asking fans to buy her album I Make the Static , VillaÂ asked that fans go online and spread her message using the hashtag #BringJoytotheWhiteHouse, a place where she hopes she will be invited to sing. 
Her video recounts the positive reaction to her gown was beyond her wildest dreams. “The explosion of my album sales, No. 1Â on iTunes, No. 1Â on Amazon, I could never have foreseen this. Honestly, I did think Iâm going to face a backlash and this that may crush my career. And I said, âYou know, this is what I have to do,'” she said. 
In an interview with Breitbart, Villa said her gown was a response to the “suppressive atmosphereâ of Hollywood. 
âI was tired of the bullying ,â she said. âI was tired of being pushed down so that I couldnât say my beliefs. And being fearful of losing sales. Losing fans. Losing bookings. Losing contracts and sponsorship. You know, thatâs my day to day. And a lot of my friends have the same thing. And we live in Hollywood, which is supposed to be the most open viewpoint city. But the truth is there was a lot of hate and a lot of negativity and I wanted to change the storyline to love and support and unity as an American.â 
Villa said being a Trump supporter in an industry that is largely against him means hiding what one truly believes. 
“It was really like a closeted feeling. And I know gay Trump supporters in my community who say, âThis feels like being closeted again. I feel like I canât come out of the closet and talk about being a Trump supporter because I will get attacked,'” she said. 
Villa said the positive reaction to her Grammys stunt far outweighed the negativity. 
âHonestly, I did get some hate,â she said. âI got some dirty looks. I got a guy who said, âI would like to step on it.â You know. I got the negativity. But they didnât come up to me and say anything except for that one person. Even at the Grammys.â 
Villa said the dress was not just about publicity. It was about changing attitudes. 
âLike hey, maybe if she is proud of what she believes in maybe I can leave her alone. Maybe I can leave my friend alone. Maybe I can leave my brother alone. Maybe I can actually still love them even though they disagree with my politics. Thatâs what we need. A little bit of tolerance,â she added.
